p.em: These exercises address the six trigonometric functions of an angle \theta in standard position as determined by the coordinates of a point on its terminal ray. \sin(\theta) = \frac{y}{r}, \quad \cos(\theta) = \frac{x}{r}, \quad \tan(\theta) = \frac{y}{x} and their reciprocals \csc(\theta) = \frac{r}{y} = \frac{1}{\sin(\theta)}, \quad \sec(\theta) = \frac{r}{x} = \frac{1}{\cos(\theta)}, \quad \cot(\theta) = \frac{x}{y} = \frac{1}{\tan(\theta)}.

statement.p: Find all six trigonometric function values of the angle \theta in standard position whose terminal ray passes through the point (x,y) = (4,-1). See figure below.
Using a calculator, approximate the coordinates (x,y) of the point on the circle indicated in the figure below.

exercise.hint: The radius of the circle appears to be r = 4.

solution.p: The radius of the circle appears to be r = 4. Using a calculator, x = 4\times\cos (121^\circ) \approx -2.06015 and y = 4\times\sin (121^\circ) \approx 3.42867. Observe the signs of each are consistent with an angle in Quadrant II.

statement.p: Suppose \theta is an angle in standard position whose terminal ray is in Quadrant III satisfying \tan (\theta) = 3. Find the sine and cosine of \theta.
Suppose \theta is an angle in standard position whose terminal ray is in Quadrant III satisfying \sin (\theta) = -1/3. Find the cosine and tangent of \theta.
Suppose the terminal ray of an angle \theta in standard position is in Quadrant IV. Which of the six trigonometric function values of \theta are positive?

solution.p:
In Quadrant IV, x \gt 0 is positive and y \lt 0 is negative. Thus,
Sine is negative; and so is its reciprocal cosecant.
Cosine is positive; and so is its reciprocal secant.
Tangent is negative; and so is its reciprocal cotangent.

p.em: These exercises address the connection between sine, cosine, and tangent and the geometry of the unit circle. We can use the reference angle and symmetry to find trigonometric functions of an angle.

statement.p: Suppose \theta is an angle in standard position. Explain what \cos (\theta), \sin(\theta), and \tan(\theta) represent geometrically in relation to the unit circle x^2+ y^2 = 1.

ul.li: \cos\theta is the x-coordinate of the point on the unit circle;
\sin\theta is the y-coordinate of the point on the unit circle;
\tan\theta is the slope of the line parallel to the terminal ray of \theta.

statement.p: Find the sine, cosine, and tangent of \theta = -90^\circ, \theta = 3\pi/2, and \theta = 5\pi by considering the corresponding the geometry of the unit circle.

ul.li:
The terminal ray of \theta = -90^\circ intersects the unit circle at (x,y) = (0,-1). So
\sin(-90^\circ) = -1, \quad \cos(-90^\circ) = 0, \quad \tan(-90^\circ) \, \rm undefined
Observe that the terminal ray is vertical so that it has no defined slope.

The terminal ray of \theta = 3\pi/2 is the same as -90^\circ. Therefore,
\sin(3\pi/2) = -1, \quad \cos(3\pi/2) = 0, \quad \tan(3\pi/2) \, \rm undefined

The terminal ray of \theta = 5\pi intersects the unit circle at (x,y) = (-1,0). So
\sin(5\pi) = 0, \quad \cos(5\pi) = -1, \quad \tan(5\pi) = 0. Observe that the terminal ray is horizontal so that it has slope zero.

statement.p: Use the reference angle approach to find the six trigonometric function values of \theta = 150^\circ, \theta = -2\pi/3, \theta = 7\pi/4, and \theta = -11\pi/4. Include a sketch in each case.
Find all angles 0 \leq \theta \lt 2\pi satisfying \sin(\theta) = -1.

solution.p: The point (0,-1) is the only point on the unit circle whose y-coordinate is -1. This corresponds to \theta = 3\pi/2. Draw a picture to confirm.

statement.p: Find all angles 0 \leq \theta \lt 2\pi satisfying \cos(\theta) = 0.

solution.p: The points (0,1) and (0,-1) are the only points on the unit circle whose x-coordinate is 0. These corresponds to \theta = 0 and \theta = \pi, respectively. Draw a picture to confirm.

statement.p: Find all angles 0 \leq \theta \lt 2\pi satisfying \tan(\theta) = -1.

solution.p: The slope of a terminal ray is -1 for \theta = 3\pi/4 and \theta = 7\pi/4. Draw a picture to confirm.

p.em: These exercises address graphing sinusoidal curves and the graphs of other trigonometric functions.

statement.p: Practice drawing the graph of y = \sin (\theta), y = \cos (\theta), and \tan(\theta) by considering the geometry of the unit circle.

hint.p: Remember that cosine is the x-coordinate and sine is the y-coordinate of the point on the unit circle determined by \theta. Tangent is the slope of the terminal ray.

statement.p: Sketch the graphs of y = - 2 \cos (\theta), y = \cos(\theta)-2, y = \cos(2\theta), and y = \cos(\theta/2).

ul.li: y=-2\cos\theta is the graph of cosine reflected over the horizontal axis and stretched vertically by a factor of 2 to give an amplitude of 2.
y=\cos\theta-2 is the graph of cosine translated down 2 units
y=\cos(2\theta) is the graph of cosine stretched horizontally by a factor of 1/2 resulting in a period of \pi.
y=\cos(\theta/2) is the graph of cosine stretched horizontally by a factor of 2 resulting in a period of 4\pi.

statement.p: Sketch one period of y=2\sin\left(3t-\frac{\pi}{4}\right). Identify the amplitude, period, and phase shift.

hint.p: First solve 3t-\frac{\pi}{4} = 0 and 3t-\frac{\pi}{4} = 2\pi for t to find where one period begins and ends, respectively.

solution.p:
To find where a period begins, solve
3t - \frac{\pi}{4} = 0 \Rightarrow t = \frac{\pi}{12}.
To find where this same period ends, solve
3t - \frac{\pi}{4} = 2\pi \Rightarrow t = \frac{3\pi}{4}.
We can plot this one period
to see that its the graph of sine shifted \pi/12 units to the right with a period of 3\pi/4 - \pi/12= 2\pi/3 and an amplitude of 2.

statement.p: Sketch one period of y=-\cos\left(2\left(t+\frac{\pi}{6}\right)\right).

hint.p: First solve 2\left(t+\frac{\pi}{6}\right) = 0 and 2\left(t+\frac{\pi}{6}\right) = 2\pi for t to find where one period begins and ends, respectively.

solution.p:
To find where a period begins, solve
2\left(t+\frac{\pi}{6}\right) = 0 \Rightarrow t = -\pi/6.
To find where this same period ends, solve
2\left(t+\frac{\pi}{6}\right) = 2\pi \Rightarrow t = 5\pi/6.
We can plot this one period
to see that its the graph of cosine reflected over the t-axis, shifted \pi/6 units to the left with a period of 5\pi/6 - (-\pi/6)= \pi and an amplitude of 1. the peak occurs at the midpoint of (5\pi/6 + (-\pi/6))/2 = \pi/3.

statement.p: Sketch one period of y = \tan(2x). Label the vertical asymptotes and at least three points on the graph for scale.

solution.p: The graph of y = \tan \theta has asymptotes where \theta = \pm \pi/2. So if 2x = \pm \pi/2 \Rightarrow x = \pm \pi/4 we will see asymptotes on y = \tan(2x). This means the period shrinks to \pi/2.

statement.p: Use the graph of y = \sin(\theta) to help you sketch the graph of its reciprocal y = \csc(\theta).

p.em: These exercises emphasize use of some important trigonometric identities. Review Appendix A of Anton (Handout). Here's a summary of summary important identities. Don't feel obligated to memorize the Addition Formulas.

answer.p:
Reciprocal identities will be helpful. Also, 1-\sin^2 \theta = \cos^2\theta, by the Pythagorean Identity.
\frac{\tan \theta \, \csc^3 \theta}{\cot^4 \theta \, \sin^5 \theta\, (1-\sin^2 \theta)} = \csc^3 \theta \sec^7 \theta

statement.p: Suppose \cos(\theta) = 0.3 and \theta is in Quadrant IV. Find the sine of the \theta using the Pythagorean Identity.
Starting with the identity \sin^2 \theta + \cos^2 \theta = 1, derive two similar identities involving tangent and cotangent, respectively.

hint.p:
Divide both sides by \cos^2\theta to see that
\tan^2 \theta + 1 = \sec^2 \theta
Divide both sides by \sin^2\theta to see that
1+\cot^2 \theta = \csc^2 \theta

statement.p:
Use the Addition Formulas and the Opposite Angle Identities to derive the Difference Formulas
\sin(\alpha - \beta) = \sin \alpha \cos \beta - \cos \alpha \sin \beta \quad \text{and} \quad \cos(\alpha-\beta) = \cos \alpha \cos \beta + \sin \alpha \sin \beta.

hint.p: Write the difference of angles as a sum \sin(\alpha - \beta) = \sin(\alpha +(-\beta)).

statement.p: Use the Difference Formulas above and the Special Triangles to find the exact values of \sin(15^\circ) and \cos(15^\circ).

hint.p: 15^\circ = 45^\circ - 30^\circ and the exact values of these can be found from the special triangles.

statement.p:
Use the Addition Formulas to derive the following Double Angle Identities
\sin (2\theta) = 2\sin\theta \cos\theta \quad \text{and} \quad \cos (2\theta) = \cos^2 \theta - \sin^2 \theta.

hint.p: Write the double angle as a sum \sin (2\theta) = \sin (\theta + \theta).

statement.p:
Use the Double Angle Identity for Cosine above to derive the Half-Angle Identities
\cos(x/2) = \pm \sqrt{\frac{1+\cos x}{2}} \quad \text{and} \quad \sin(x/2) = \pm \sqrt{\frac{1-\cos x}{2}}.

solution.p:
I'll do one. From the double angle identity:
\cos(2\theta) &= \cos^2 \theta - \sin^2 \theta
&= 1-\sin^2 \theta - \sin^2 \theta
\cos(2\theta)&= 1-2\sin^2 \theta
Solve this last equation for \sin^2 \theta,
\sin^2 \theta = \frac{1-\cos(2\theta)}{2}
Thus,
\sin \theta =\pm\sqrt{\frac{1-\cos(2\theta)}{2}},
where the sign is determined by the quadrant \theta is in. Let \theta = x/2, then 2\theta = x and
\sin (x/2) =\pm\sqrt{\frac{1-\cos(x)}{2}}.
